title: Alison Phillips: Only by walking off pitch can we stop vile racist outrages
text:

So let’s think this through... how would we feel?

How would we feel if our kids went to work this morning and as they took off their coat, got out their packed lunch and prepared themselves for the job ahead, the racist chanting began?

And how would we feel if as they settled down to their work, the chanting became louder and louder; monkey noises and far-right salutes?

“Alright lads, knock it on the head now,” says the boss. And so the racists quieten down – for a bit. Some of them clear off. But soon there are enough of them at it again.

The intimidation continues, along with the unspoken threat that this is exactly how they will behave tomorrow, and the next day, and whenever else they fancy.

(Image: Getty Images)

For when has a bully ever stopped voluntarily?

I don’t know a single parent who wouldn’t give their child in that situation just one piece of advice: “Get the hell out of there straight away. You don’t have to listen to that. And don’t go back until the bosses have stopped it.”

And there is absolutely no difference to that and what our England team withstood on Monday night.

A football stadium is the factory floor for Tyrone Mings and Marcus Rashford.

And there’s no reason why – just because they’re paid to entertain people – they shouldn’t be protected in the same way as someone paid to assemble cars or file insurance claims.

And yet UEFA – the bosses of European football – has time and again failed to protect its workers.

Everyone knew racist incidents were likely at the Bulgaria game, and yet dozens of thugs still got into the ground – many wearing “No Respect” tops as a two-finger salute to the Respect banners draped ineffectively around the stadium. The England players – and fans – behaved brilliantly.

And the stopping of the match twice showed these players are no longer prepared to carry on and pretend to ignore abuse as they’ve done so many times before. A line has been crossed.

And yet...

(Image: PA)

And yet they still played on through the second half when abuse continued. They still completed a match which should have been abandoned long before.

And why should anyone watching – either in the stadium or at home – have to witness it too? Why should any parent in front of the TV have had to explain to their football fanatical child why that chanting was going on – and why no one was making it stop?

And why does UEFA talk about zero-tolerance for racism when in actual fact it’s three-chances-and-we’ll-hope-no-one-hears-anything-after-the-second-warning tolerance? Only when a team of players walk together off a pitch will those who run football finally root this out.

If UEFA were guided by morality, it would have done it years ago. Financial penalties and global shame are the only levers our players have left. They must use them.

And we mustn’t kid ourselves that this is a “foreign” problem. There have been way too many incidents of racism at our own grounds recently.

(Image: Getty Images)

Inevitably, what happens at international and national games is copied at lower league games, at Sunday league matches, at under-10s park football, and at kids lobbing rolled-up socks down the street.

So how England’s youngsters were treated on Monday night really is how any of our youngsters will be treated – if we allow it.

It’s time we told all our kids: “It’s OK to get the hell out of there. You don’t have to listen to that.”
description: Mirror columnist Alison Phillips on why England match against Bulgaria should have been abandoned after racist chants
